sections.name: Ability Scores
sections.content: Every character has six ability scores that represent their basic attributes: Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma. These scores range from 3 to 18 for most characters, with 10-11 being the average for humans. Modifiers derived from ability scores range from -4 to +4 for most characters, with 0 being average.

subsections.name: Strength
subsections.content: Strength measures physical power and affects melee attack rolls, damage rolls with melee weapons, athletics checks, and carrying capacity.

subsections.name: Dexterity
subsections.content: Dexterity measures agility and affects armor class, initiative, ranged attack rolls, and dexterity saves.

subsections.name: Constitution
subsections.content: Constitution measures endurance and affects hit points, constitution saves, and concentration checks for spellcasters.

subsections.name: Intelligence
subsections.content: Intelligence measures reasoning and memory, affecting knowledge-based skills and spellcasting for wizards.

subsections.name: Wisdom
subsections.content: Wisdom measures perception and insight, affecting perception checks, insight checks, and spellcasting for clerics and druids.

subsections.name: Charisma
subsections.content: Charisma measures force of personality, affecting social interactions, persuasion checks, and spellcasting for bards, sorcerers, and warlocks.

sections.name: Dice Rolls
sections.content: Most actions in D&D 5e are resolved by rolling dice. The most common roll is the d20 roll, used for attack rolls, saving throws, and ability checks. To make a d20 roll, roll a 20-sided die and add any relevant modifiers.

subsections.name: Advantage and Disadvantage
subsections.content: When you have advantage on a roll, roll two d20s and take the higher result. When you have disadvantage, roll two d20s and take the lower result.

subsections.name: Critical Hits
subsections.content: When you roll a 20 on an attack roll, you score a critical hit, which means you roll twice as many damage dice.

sections.name: Combat
sections.content: Combat in D&D 5e takes place in rounds, each lasting approximately 6 seconds in game time. During a round, each participant takes a turn, acting in order of initiative.

subsections.name: Initiative
subsections.content: At the start of combat, everyone rolls initiative by making a Dexterity check. The order of initiative determines the order of turns during combat.

subsections.name: Actions
subsections.content: On your turn, you can take one action, such as Attack, Cast a Spell, Dash, Disengage, Dodge, Help, Hide, Ready, Search, or Use an Object.

subsections.name: Bonus Actions
subsections.content: Some abilities and spells allow you to take a bonus action on your turn, in addition to your regular action.

subsections.name: Reactions
subsections.content: Some abilities and spells allow you to take a reaction, which is an instant response to a trigger. You can take only one reaction per round.
